question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Questions}. Questions 1-4 are short-answer
questions. Put your answers in the boxes provided. \textbf{Simplify your
answers as much as possible, and show your work}. Each question is worth
3 marks, but not all questions are of equal difficulty.

Evaluate

$\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{e^{3x^{2}}-1}{\sin(x^{2})}$
sols:
Plugging in $x=0$ in the limit gives an indeterminant form $0/0$ and so
we may attempt to use L'Hopital's rule to get

$\lim_{x \to 0}\frac{e^{3x^{2}}-1}{\sin(x^{2})} = \lim_{x \to 0}\frac{6xe^{3x^{2}}}{2x\cos(x^{2})}= \lim_{x \to 0}\frac{3e^{3x^{2}}}{\cos(x^{2})} = \frac{3e^{0}}{1}=3$
hints:
Failing L'Hopital's rule (or if you don't know it) one can also use
Taylor polynomials.
